questions.text: Ribbon candy appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by linear deposits of IgG and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction, which on immunofluorescence shows a characteristic "Ribbon candy" appearance due to smooth, continuous linear staining along the basement membrane zone.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Pemphigus vulgaris: Immunofluorescence shows a "fish-net" or reticular pattern due to intercellular IgG deposits.
  • (Choice C) Pemphigus foliaceous: Similar to pemphigus vulgaris, it also shows an intercellular "fish-net" pattern.
  • (Choice D) Dermatitis herpetiformis: Immunofluorescence reveals granular deposits of IgA at dermal papilla tips, not a linear "ribbon candy" appearance.

Thus, option (B) is correct.

questions.text: 20 year old female presents with blisters over skin and in oral cavity. Her skin biopsy shows a special pattern on immunofluorescence. What is incorrect regarding this disorder?
questions.solution:
This case describes Pemphigus Vulgaris:

A young female patient (20 years old) with blisters involving both the skin and oral cavity strongly suggests Pemphigus Vulgaris.

The provided immunofluorescence image shows the classic "fish-net" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to deposition of IgG antibodies between epidermal keratinocytes.

(Choice B) Antibodies against desmoglein 3 (Correct statement):

The hallmark antibody of pemphigus vulgaris.

Desmoglein 3 is highly expressed in the oral mucosa, explaining severe oral involvement.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice (A) (Incorrect statement):

Antibodies against desmoglein 1 primarily occur in Pemphigus foliaceus, which affects only the superficial skin layers and typically has no oral involvement.

Pemphigus vulgaris, which has prominent oral involvement, primarily targets desmoglein 3. It may sometimes also involve desmoglein 1, but desmoglein 3 antibodies are predominant.

Choice (C & D) (implicitly correct):

Typically, pemphigus vulgaris shows an intercellular IgG deposition pattern on immunofluorescence, producing the characteristic fish-net appearance demonstrated clearly in the provided image

questions.text: Breast biopsy shows the following histopathological image. The tumour cells show PAS positivity. What is your most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
The histopathological image demonstrates large, pale-staining cells with abundant clear cytoplasm scattered singly or in clusters within the epidermis. These cells are known as Paget cells, characteristic of Paget's disease of the breast.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Ductal carcinoma: Typically presents as invasive clusters or nests of tumor cells within breast stroma, not epidermis.
  • (Choice C) Inflammatory carcinoma: Clinical presentation includes erythema and edema ("peau d'orange") of breast skin. Histologically, dermal lymphatics are blocked by carcinoma cells, not epidermal infiltration.
  • (Choice D) Lobular carcinoma: Usually characterized by small cells infiltrating the stroma in a single-file pattern, not epidermal involvement.

Thus, the correct diagnosis is Paget's disease (Choice A).

Key takeaway:

  • Large cells with clear cytoplasm (Paget cells) interspersed among keratinocytes.
  • PAS positivity is a hallmark, reflecting intracellular mucopolysaccharides within Paget cells.

Clinical correlation typically shows an eczematous lesion involving the nipple and areola

questions.text: Golf ball inclusions are seen on ___ stain and are associated with deletion of ____ alpha genes?
questions.solution:
• (C) New methylene blue-3 (Correct Answer)
    Explanation:
    "Golf ball inclusions" are characteristically seen in Hemoglobin H disease, which occurs due to deletion of three alpha-globin genes (--/-α). These inclusions represent precipitated beta-chain tetramers (HbH bodies) and are best visualized using supravital stains, specifically new methylene blue.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice A) Romanowsky-1
    Explanation:
    Romanowsky stains (e.g., Wright or Leishman stain) are commonly used for peripheral blood smears but do not effectively demonstrate "golf ball inclusions", nor are these inclusions associated with deletion of only one alpha gene.
  • (Choice B) Giemsa stain-2
    Explanation:
    Giemsa stain, another Romanowsky stain variant, also does not highlight golf ball inclusions clearly, and deletion of two alpha genes causes alpha-thalassemia trait (α-thalassemia minor), typically without these inclusions.
  • (Choice D) New methylene blue-4
    Explanation:
    Deletion of four alpha genes (--/--) results in Hydrops Fetalis with Hb Bart's, a fatal condition incompatible with life. In this condition, golf ball inclusions (HbH bodies) are not typically seen due to absence of alpha chains entirely, and instead, gamma chains form Hb Bart's.

questions.text: Identify the cell
questions.solution:
Echinocyte is a second name for Burr cells.

Choice D: Echinocyte

  • Echinocytes (Burr cells) are red blood cells with evenly spaced, short, blunt projections.
  • They are seen in conditions such as uremia, pyruvate kinase deficiency, and post-transfusion states.
  • Unlike acanthocytes, the projections of echinocytes are more uniform in size and distribution.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Acanthocyte

  • Acanthocytes have irregular, spiky projections with sharp ends (unlike the uniform projections of echinocytes).
  • Seen in abetalipoproteinemia and liver disease.

Choice B: Dacrocyte

  • Dacrocytes (teardrop cells) appear elongated with a pointed end.
  • Seen in myelofibrosis, thalassemia, and bone marrow infiltration disorders.

Choice C: Degmacyte

  • Degmacytes (bite cells) have a characteristic semicircular "bite" taken out of them.
  • Seen in G6PD deficiency, where oxidative stress causes Heinz bodies, leading to RBC membrane damage.

Key Takeaway: Acanthocyte possess irregular spicules having sharp ends. Such cells are seen in abetalipoproteinemia and pyruvate kinase deficiency (Fig. 1.105).

Barr cells possess uniform projections in size and are regularly spaced. These are observed in cases of uremia [Fig. 1.106]

Dacrocytes, also known as teardrop cells, are red blood cells that are seen in conditions such as myelofibrosis, leukemia, and thalassemia.

Degmacytes, also known as bite cells, are abnormally shaped red blood cells that are commonly seen in blood smears. They are often found in people with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
